Graphical abstract An effective strategy coupling the blocking with dredging to stop the polysulfide shuttle has been provided through constructing a novel three-in-one functional separator. The lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery, as one of the energy storage devices, has been in the limelight due to its high theoretical energy density. However, the poor redox kinetics and the “shuttle effect” of polysulfides severely restrict the use of Li-S batteries in practical applications. Herein, a novel bimetallic LaNiO3 functional material with high electrical conductivity and catalytic property is prepared to act as a high-efficiency polysulfide shuttling stopper. The three LaNiO3 samples with different physical/chemical characteristics are obtained by controlling the calcination temperature. In conjunction with the high electrical conductivity and excellent catalytic properties of the as-prepared materials, the appropriate chemisorption toward polysulfides offers great potential to enhance electrochemical stability for high-performance Li-S batteries. Particularly, the Li-S cell with the separator modified by such functional material gives a specific capacity of 658 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles at a high current density of 2 C. Even with high sulfur loading of 6.05 mg cm−2, the Li-S battery still exhibits an areal specific capacity of 2.81 mA h cm−2 after 150 cycles. This work paves a new avenue for the rational design of materials for separator modification in high-performance Li-S batteries. Keywords Li-S battery Functional separator Catalytic property Electrochemical stability Redox kinetics 1 Introduction The lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries possessing high energy density (2600 W h kg−1), environmental friendliness, and low cost are ideal energy storage devices for artificial intelligence devices, smart grids, electric vehicles, etc. [1–5]. Nevertheless, the commercialization of Li-S batteries faces serious challenges, including limited conductivity of active sulfur compounds, sluggish conversion between charge and discharge products, and a strong shuttle effect caused by the soluble polysulfides (Li2S x , 4 ≤ x ≤ 8) [6–10]. Therefore, it is crucial to collect polysulfides at the cathode side and to promote their conversion reaction for developing high-performance Li-S batteries [11–16]. The electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries can be improved by constructing positive electrode materials, adopting suitable binders, optimizing electrolytes, and protecting the lithium anode [17–21]. In addition, preparing multifunctional composite separators with strong affinity is also a simple and effective strategy to improve their performance [22–25]. The modification of commercial separators is one of the primary research methods used nowadays due to its simplicity and viability. For example, the separator is modified with a variety of carbon materials, whose excellent conductivity and distinctive pore structure can promote rapid electron transfer and physically bond with the polysulfides [26–29]. Although carbon materials offer several advantages for battery applications, the shuttle effect cannot be effectively suppressed because of their poor affinity to polysulfides. Compared with physical adsorption, the application of chemical adsorption in Li-S batteries is particularly important. Therefore, polar polymers and metal compounds have been frequently employed to modify the separator resulting from their superior anchoring effect on polysulfides [30–32]. However, the polysulfide conversion kinetics on most polymers and metal compounds is very sluggish, due to their poor electronic conductivity and catalytic property, resulting in the failure of the functional separators and low utilization of sulfur active species [33–37]. Consequently, a rational material for the modification of separator is required, which blocks the polysulfides and increases their consumption to improve durability. Nonetheless, it presently remains a challenge to design and develop the material for separator modification that has simultaneously high conductivity, strong affinity, and catalytic performance. Meanwhile, the synergistic effects of polysulfide affinity, electrical conductivity, and catalytic property on battery performance are rarely studied. Perovskite-type LaNiO3 possessing good catalytic performance and structural stability prepared by sputtering, pulsed laser deposition, and sol-gel technique are widely utilized in electrode materials, conductive transparent films, catalysis, sensors, and so forth [38–42]. For the first time, LaNiO3 is adopted as the modification material to construct a three-in-one composite separator boosting electrochemical stability and redox kinetics for Li-S batteries. Firstly, LaNiO3 material has a good adsorption effect on polysulfides and can inhibit the shuttle of polysulfides to a certain extent during battery operation. Secondly, LaNiO3 material has excellent conductivity to promote fast electron transport for adsorbent polysulfides. Finally, LaNiO3 material has wonderful catalytic ability for polysulfide conversion to significantly improve the redox kinetics. Therefore, we provide an effective strategy coupling the blocking with dredging to stop the polysulfide shuttle. The three-in-one functional separator can not only block the polysulfides but also quickly convert them without aggregation, thus effectively keeping its durability. Notably, the Li-S cell with 800 °C LaNiO3-separator and high sulfur loading of 6.05 mg cm−2 provides an area-specific capacity of 2.81 mA h cm−2 after 150 cycles. Further, the Li-S battery with 800 °C LaNiO3-separator provides a high area-specific capacity of 5.98 mA h cm−2 after 40 cycles under a sulfur loading of 12.45 mg cm−2 with 7 µL mg−1 electrolyte. This study gives a fresh perspective on the rational design of the materials for separator modification for high-performance Li-S batteries. 2 Experimental 2.1 Synthesis of LaNiO3 functional materials The bimetallic oxide LaNiO3 was synthesized via a sol-gel technique. Firstly, solution A was prepared by dissolving 0.08 mol L−1 La(NO3)3·6H2O, 0.08 mol L−1 Ni(NO3)2·6H2O, and 0.24 mol L−1 polyvinylpyrrolidone (PVP) in 25 mL deionized water and was kept stirring for 15 min at room temperature. Solution B was prepared by taking 0.24 mol L−1 citric acid solution. Thereafter, solutions A and B were mixed and stirred at 80 °C for 2–3 h to obtain a light green sol, followed by drying in an oven at 120 °C for 24 h. The resultant material was ground and calcined for 8 h at 600, 800, and 1000 °C, separately, and the samples were denoted as 600 °C LaNiO3, 800 °C LaNiO3, and 1000 °C LaNiO3, respectively. The as-prepared catalysts were finally ball-milled at a rate of 300 r min−1 for 1 h to decrease the particle size. 2.2 Material characterization The morphology and particle size of the as-prepared samples were obtained using a scanning electron microscope (SEM, S-4800, Hitachi) and transmission electron microscope (TEM, JEM-2100F, JEOL). The powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were carried out using a Bruker D8 Advance powder X-ray diffractometer with a scan speed of 5° min−1 in the 2θ range of 20°–90°. The chemical state of LaNiO3 catalysts before and after the adsorption of polysulfides was analyzed with X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) conducted on the Thermo Scientific 250Xi X-ray photoelectron spectrometer. In situ Raman measurements of Li-S batteries were conducted on Renishaw inVia Raman spectrometers. 2.3 Electrochemical measurements The 800 °C LaNiO3, super P, and polyvinylidene fluoride (PVDF) binder were uniformly mixed in N-methyl-2-pyrrolidone (NMP) in a mass ratio of 6:3:1, and the resulting slurry was evenly coated on the commercial Celgard 2325 separator. The separator was vacuum dried at 60 °C for 12 h in an oven to prepare the three-in-one functional separator. Meanwhile, the control samples, 600 °C LaNiO3-separator, 1000 °C LaNiO3-separator (with the same mass ratio of the sample as mentioned above), and super P-separator (super P and PVDF with a mass ratio of 9:1) were prepared using the same procedure. The sulfur powder and super P were mixed by grinding in a mass ratio of 6:4 or 8:2. The resulting mixture was transferred into a 50 mL Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and heated at 155 °C for 12 h to obtain the S/super P composite. The cathode was prepared by uniformly mixing 80 wt% S/super P composite, 10 wt% Ketjenblack (KB), and 10 wt% PVDF binder in NMP. Afterward, the mixed slurry was blade-coated on the Al foil and vacuum dried at 60 °C for 12 h to obtain the S electrode. The S loading was kept at around 0.7 mg cm−2. Next, the as-prepared S cathode, a functional separator, and a lithium anode were assembled into a CR2016 cell in a glove box filled with Ar. The 30 µL of electrolyte containing 1 M LiTFSI in a 1,2-dimethoxyethane and 1,3-dioxolame (1:1 v/v) mixed solvent with 2% LiNO3 was added to the cell. The assembled battery was tested on a LAND CT2001A battery test system at room temperature. The cyclic voltammetry (CV) study was conducted on CHI660E electrochemical workstation under a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1. Further, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) tests were performed on the same instrument in a frequency range from 10 mHz to 100 kHz with an amplitude of 5 mV. In order to prepare in-situ cells, sulfur cathodes were prepared by containing 80 wt% S/super P composite, 10 wt% KB, and 10 wt% PVDF binder. Then, 800 °C LaNiO3, super P, and PVDF binder were uniformly mixed in NMP in a mass ratio of 6:3:1, and the resulting slurry was evenly coated on the as-prepared sulfur cathode. In-situ cells (Gao Shi Rui Lian (Tianjin) Photoelectric Technology Co., Ltd. Model 19004) with 1 cm × 1 cm sulfur cathode coated with 800 °C LaNiO3 and a lithium anode were assembled. After the in-situ cell was assembled in the glove box and filled with electrolyte, it was tested on the LAND CT2001A system at a current density of 0.2 C for 1 h. The S/super P composite with a 6:4 ratio was employed to prepare high-loading electrodes. The high-loading S cathode was prepared by evenly coating slurry on carbon paper with a controlled S loading in the range of 2.56–12.45 mg cm−2. For lean electrolyte test, the amount of electrolyte added to the battery with S loading of 12.45 mg cm−2 was 7 μL mg−1. Further, to explore the practical application potential of 800 °C LaNiO3-separator, S/super P composites with an 8:2 ratio were used to prepare high-loading electrodes with S loading and electrolyte content of 5.14 mg cm−2 and 8 µL mg−1, respectively. 2.4 Polysulfide adsorption A 0.1 mol L−1 Li2S6 solution was prepared by mixing Li2S and sulfur powder in 6 mL tetrahydrofuran (THF) with a molar ratio of 1:5, followed by stirring and heating at 65 °C for 48 h. Later, the prepared solution was diluted to 2 mmol L−1 for polysulfide adsorption. Then, four different glass bottles were added separately with 160 mg of 600 °C LaNiO3, 800 °C LaNiO3, 1000 °C LaNiO3, and super P, followed by adding the same volume of 2 mmol L−1 Li2S6 solution in each bottle. Thereafter, the bottles containing LaNiO3 functional materials were placed in a glove box filled with Ar for about 48 h before the supernatant was taken out and injected into the quartz cuvette. The supernatant solution was then analyzed using UV-visible absorption spectrophotometry (Metash UV-8000), and the residual amount of Li2S6 in the solution was quantitatively determined after the adsorption test. 2.5 Symmetric cell tests For this study, Li2S and sulfur powder with a molar ratio of 1:5 were stirred in the mixed solvent (DOL:DME = 1:1 v/v) at 65 °C for 48 h in the glove box to obtain a 0.1 mol L−1 Li2S6 solution. LaNiO3 (600 °C, 800 °C, and 1000 °C, respectively), super P, and PVDF binder were mixed in NMP to obtain a uniform slurry. The slurry was coated on Al foil and then vacuum dried at 60 °C for 12 h. Two identical as-prepared electrodes and Li2S6 solution were utilized to assemble symmetrical cells in the glove box. Then, a CV test was carried out at a scan rate of 10 mV s−1 using a CHI660E electrochemical workstation. The super P-electrode (super P:PVDF = 9:1) was also tested by the same method. 2.6 Li2S nucleation experiments A 0.2 mol L−1 Li2S8 solution was prepared by dissolving Li2S and sulfur powder in tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether in a molar ratio of 1:7 under stirring and heating at 65 °C for 48 h. The cathode made of carbon paper dispersed with 800 °C LaNiO3, Li anode, and Celgard 2325 separator were used for battery assembly. Then, 25 μL Li2S8 and 25 μL electrolyte (1 M LiTFSI in tetraethylene glycol dimethyl ether) were added to the cathode and the anode sides, respectively. The cell was discharged on the Neware battery test system (CT-ZWJ-4′S-T-1U) at a constant current of 0.112 mA to a potential of 2.06 V and then kept at 2.05 V until the current was less than 10−3 mA. For comparison, the 600 °C LaNiO3 and 1000 °C LaNiO3 samples were also tested by the same process. 2.7 DFT computations Density functional theory (DFT) calculations were carried out using the Projector-Augmented Wave (PAW) method as implemented in the Vienna Ab Initio Simulation Package (VASP) [43]. The Perdew-Burke-Erzenhoff (PBE) form of the generalized gradient approximation (GGA) was employed to describe exchange and correlation effects [44]. A Hubbard U parameter of 4.0 eV was chosen for the Ni d-states in all calculations [45]. The optimized lattice parameters are a = 5.43 Å and c = 6.65 Å for bulk hexagonal perovskite LaNiO3, which is in good agreement with our experimental values of a = 5.46 Å and c = 6.57 Å. The (001) surface of La2O3 and LaNiO3 was chosen because of the lowest surface energy [45,46]. A k-point mesh of 2 × 2 × 1, an energy cutoff of 500 eV as well as an energy convergence criterion of 0.0001 eV was used for surface calculations. The Gibbs free energies of S8, Li2S8, Li2S6, Li2S4, Li2S2, and Li2S were calculated by the intermediate steps in Table S1. 3 Results and discussion Fig. 1 (a–f) corresponds to the SEM and TEM images of the materials prepared at 600, 800, and 1000 °C respectively. It is evident from images that the materials contain nanoparticles, and the particle size increases with increasing calcination temperature. The material calcined at 1000 °C has an obvious aggregation with large particle size and low specific surface area. Fig. 1(g) presents the XRD patterns of different materials, exhibiting diffraction peaks at 2θ = 32.75°, 47.31°, 58.50°, 69.68°, 78.47°, and 84.22° corresponding to (110), (202), (300), (024), (312), and (205) crystal planes of LaNiO3 (PDF#33-0711). It also demonstrates that increasing the calcination temperature from 600 to 800 °C reduces the impurity phase in LaNiO3 and improves its crystallinity. However, a new impurity phase occurs when the calcination temperature increases to 1000 °C. After analysis, it is found that the material calcined at 600 °C contains a large amount of LaO2CO3 and NiO. At the same time, it is found that the material calcined at 1000 °C also has heterogeneous peaks of La2O3 and NiO impurities (Fig. S1). The high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) image shown in Fig. S2(a) displays lattice plane spacings of 0.273, 1.577, and 1.921 nm, which are assigned to the (110), (300), and (202) crystal planes of LaNiO3, respectively. In addition, the elemental mappings (Fig. 1h) display that the La, O, and Ni elements are evenly dispersed throughout the material. In general, there will be oxygen vacancies in the material calcined in air [47,48]. The electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra in Fig. 1(i) depict that the LaNiO3 materials prepared at different temperatures exhibit strong EPR signals at g = 2.00, indicating the presence of oxygen vacancies in LaNiO3 materials [6,49]. Moreover, several pits are clearly observed on the surface of the material from the HRTEM image, intuitively reflecting the defects in LaNiO3 (Fig. S2b). Interestingly, the existence of oxygen vacancies in the structure of the LaNiO3 catalyst could provide reaction sites, facilitating the electrochemical reactions and thereby promoting the redox kinetics of Li-S batteries [50,51]. To prepare LaNiO3 functionalized separator, LaNiO3 nanoparticles, super P, and PVDF binder in a mass ratio of 6:3:1 were blade-coated on a commercial Celgard 2325 separator. The amount of the 800 °C LaNiO3 coated on the separator was controlled at around 0.24 mg cm−2. Meanwhile, the as-prepared 800 °C LaNiO3-separator was folded multiple times to confirm the strong adhesion between the LaNiO3 composite coating and Celgard 2325 noted as PP separator. As shown in Fig. 2 (a), the composite separator remains intact even after multiple folding, with no signs of material shedding. In addition, Fig. S3 shows that the LaNiO3 functional layer still adheres to the PP separator after the cycle. Furthermore, as displayed in the cross-sectional SEM image of the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator, the thickness of the coating layer is seen to be 4.56 µm (Fig. 2b). Moreover, the top-view SEM image of the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator shown in Fig. 2(c) illustrates that the super P conductive carbon matrix evenly wraps the LaNiO3 functional material. Furthermore, this is again confirmed by the elemental mappings analysis, where the elements C, La, Ni, and O are uniformly dispersed on the separator, as shown in Fig. 2(d–g). The Li+ conductivity of the PP separator and 800 °C LaNiO3-separator was tested using EIS analysis (Fig. S4). Clearly, the internal resistance of Li-S batteries coated with LaNiO3 does not increase. The effect of LaNiO3 materials on the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries were evaluated by electrochemical tests at room temperature. Fig. 3 (a) shows the CV curve of Li-S battery with 800 °C LaNiO3-separator in the voltage range of 1.8–2.6 V. The peak at 2.30 V represents the formation of long-chain polysulfides (Li2S x , 4 ≤ x ≤ 8) [19,52], whereas the peak at 2.01 V represents the conversion of Li2S x to Li2S2/Li2S [53,54]. The figure also shows the CV curve (purple line) of the coin cell prepared using a mixture of 80 wt% 800 °C LaNiO3, 10 wt% super P, and 10 wt% PVDF as the cathode, demonstrating the electrochemical stability of the 800 °C LaNiO3 under the potential window of the Li-S batteries. Furthermore, the CV curves of the Li-S batteries with 600 °C LaNiO3-separator, 1000 °C LaNiO3-separator, super P-separator, and PP separator at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1 are shown in Fig. S5. Notably, they exhibit similar redox behaviors when compared to Li-S battery with the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator, suggesting that coated materials on separators do not affect the redox behavior of batteries. In addition, it is observed that the peak current of the Li-S battery with the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator is generally higher than that of the Li-S battery using the PP separator during the first CV scan, illustrating the high reaction activity of the former (Fig. S6). Furthermore, in the first scan, the ΔE1 and ΔE2 values of the Li-S battery with the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator are 7 and 26 mV, respectively, which are lower than those of the Li-S battery with the PP separator, indicating its lower polarization [49]. Fig. 3(b) depicts the charge-discharge curves of the Li-S battery with 800 °C LaNiO3-separator, showing the typical double-platform discharge behavior of the system. The higher platform around 2.3 V results from the conversion of S8 to liquid Li2S x (4 ≤ x ≤ 8), while the lower long platform around 2.1 V represents the transformation of liquid polysulfides to solid Li2S2/Li2S [17,55]. Next, the cycle performance of Li-S batteries utilizing 800 °C LaNiO3-separator, 600 °C LaNiO3-separator, 1000 °C LaNiO3-separator, super P-separator, and PP separator was studied at the current density of 2 C to validate their application in Li-S batteries (Fig. 3c). It is worth mentioning that the Li-S battery using 800 °C LaNiO3-separator displays excellent cycling stability at a current density of 2 C. Meanwhile, the capacity reaches 830 mA h g−1 after 200 cycles. In contrast, the capacities of Li-S batteries with 600 °C LaNiO3-separator, 1000 °C LaNiO3-separator, super P-separator, and PP separator are 678, 595, 509, and 317 mA h g−1, respectively, which are much lower than that of Li-S batteries using 800 °C LaNiO3-separator. Further, the charge and discharge curves of Li-S batteries with 800 °C LaNiO3-separator and commercial PP separator after 200 cycles are compared in Fig. S7. Noticeably, the polarization potential of Li-S battery utilizing 800 °C LaNiO3-separator is smaller, implying the reduced polarization and quicker redox kinetics during cycling. In addition, theoretically the Li-S cells have a Q L/Q H value of 3, where Q H is the capacity of high platform, Q L is the capacity of low platform [56,57]. The Q H, Q L, and Q L/Q H values of a Li-S battery with the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator are 280, 830 mA h g−1, and 2.96, respectively (Fig. S7). In contrast, the three values for the PP separator are found to be 109, 317 mA h g−1, and 2.91. A higher capacity and Q L/Q H value suggest that 800 °C LaNiO3 can effectively hinder the shuttle effect and improve the utilization of sulfur active materials. Fig. 3(d) depicts the rate properties of Li-S batteries with various separators. Even at a high current density of 8 C, the Li-S battery using the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator provides a high specific capacity of 606 mA h g−1. However, the cell utilizing the PP separator exhibits a specific capacity of 186 mA h g−1 at a current density of 8 C. Moreover, the discharge curve of the Li-S battery with the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator still maintains the double plateau characteristic at a high current density of 8 C, in contrast to the Li-S battery with the PP separator, where the dual plateau characteristic disappears due to the high polarization and sluggish redox kinetics (Fig. 3e and f). To further highlight the advantages of the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator, the S loading was increased to 2.2 mg cm−2 for rate property test (Fig. S8). The Li-S battery with 800 °C LaNiO3-separator can deliver a high specific capacity of 857 mA h g−1 even at a current density of 0.6 C, which is much higher than that with 600 °C LaNiO3-separator (606 mA h g−1) and 1000 °C LaNiO3-separator (461 mA h g−1). Meanwhile, under the current densities of 0.5, 1, and 2 C, the capacity of Li-S batteries using the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator stays at 594, 662, and 658 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles with their corresponding capacity decay of 0.1%, 0.09%, and 0.09% per cycle, demonstrating their excellent long-term cycle performance. In addition, the Li-S battery with 800 °C LaNiO3-separator still shows high Coulombic efficiency above 99.1% after 500 cycles at different current densities, indicating that the shuttle effect of polysulfides is suppressed (Fig. 3g). The Li-S batteries using the separators with different loadings of 800 °C LaNiO3 (0.10, 0.16, 0.24 mg cm−2) can still have stable long cycling performance at a current density of 2 C. After 300 cycles, the specific capacities of 602, 668, and 794 mA h g−1 can be maintained, respectively. It can be seen from the Fig. S9 that the difference in cycling performance of Li-S batteries using different-loading separators is acceptable. To further highlight that the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator effectively blocks polysulfides, the battery was assembled without a LiNO3 additive in the electrolyte. According to previous reports, LiNO3 can produce a stable and homogeneous passivation film on the Li anode during the operation of the Li-S battery, thus, effectively blocking the transport of polysulfides [58,59]. As shown in Fig. 3(h), the Li-S battery with 800 °C LaNiO3-separator can still obtain a high capacity of 653 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles at 2 C. However, the Li-S battery with PP separator can give a low capacity of 371 mA h g−1 after 300 cycles at 2 C. Moreover, due to the severe shuttle effect, the Li-S battery with PP separator shows low Coulombic efficiency. The results further emphasize that the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator can effectively inhibit the shuttle of polysulfides and improve the cycling performance of Li-S batteries. In order to illustrate the potential of the as-prepared Li-S battery in the practical application, the S content in the cathode was increased from 48% to 64%. The cell containing the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator displays good cycling performance at various current densities, especially at 0.5 C, where the capacity of the Li-S battery remains 614 mA h g−1 even after 300 cycles (Fig. S10). The improved cycling stability of Li-S battery with LaNiO3 functionalized separator is firstly caused by their strong affinity towards polysulfides. In order to observe the strong affinity of LaNiO3 to polysulfides intuitively, the polysulfide adsorption tests were carried out. The initial Li2S6 solution is yellow (inset in Fig. 4 a). The addition of super P into the Li2S6 solution does not change its color, as it remains yellow after 48 h. However, adding LaNiO3 nanoparticles prepared at different calcination temperatures to the solution and allowing it to rest for about 48 h make the color of the solution significantly lighter, especially for 600 °C LaNiO3 and 800 °C LaNiO3. As shown in Fig. S11, the adsorption performance difference can be explained by different specific surface area. In order to quantitatively characterize the residue of Li2S6 in the solution, the supernatant in the bottle was analyzed by UV-visible absorption spectrophotometry. It is found that the intensity of the characteristic peak of polysulfides decreases noticeably, particularly in the case of the 600 °C LaNiO3 and 800 °C LaNiO3 (Fig. 4a). Besides, the adsorption interactions are investigated from the XPS spectra of 800 °C LaNiO3 before and after the adsorption of Li2S6 (Fig. S12). It is observed that the shift of the main peaks corresponding to La 3d and Ni 2p implies a strong chemical interaction between 800 °C LaNiO3 and polysulfides [38,60]. The SEM images of the change in the surface morphology of the Li anode after cycling tests are shown in Fig. S13. It can be seen that a substantial amount of deposits covers the surface of the Li anode from the Li-S battery with PP separator after circulation. Meanwhile, owing to the strong affinity of LaNiO3 to polysulfides, there are fewer deposits on the surface of the Li anode from the Li-S battery using LaNiO3-modified separators. Interestingly, the surface of the Li anode from the Li-S battery with the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator is the smoothest, despite the fact that the adsorption performance of the material is not the best. Next, a super P-separator (super P: PVDF = 9: 1) was applied to eliminate the effect of super P on the battery performance. It is noticed that the surface of the Li anode is covered with a large amount of deposits after 50 cycles of Li-S battery employing a super P-separator at 2 C. Therefore, the significantly suppressed shuttle effect by the 800 °C LaNiO3 is mainly attributed to other key properties of LaNiO3 induced by the differences in morphology and structure. Firstly, the conductivity of LaNiO3 nanoparticles prepared at various temperatures was studied using the four-probe technique under different pressures. According to Fig. 4(b), the 800 °C LaNiO3 possesses much higher conductivity than 600 °C LaNiO3 and 1000 °C LaNiO3 nanoparticles, indicating a fast electron transfer pathway for rapid polysulfide conversion. Later, the EIS measurements were employed to study the dynamic behavior of Li-S batteries with different separators. Compared to other separators, the battery with the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator has a low charge transfer impedance indicating that high conductivity improves the redox kinetics of the battery (Fig. S14). Secondly, the catalytic performance of the LaNiO3 prepared at different temperatures was studied using the assembled symmetric batteries with the 600 °C, 800 °C, 1000 °C LaNiO3 electrode, and super P electrode. Evidently, the cell with the 800 °C LaNiO3 electrode exhibits the largest redox current caused by the polysulfide conversion, as displayed in Fig. 4(c), indicating the accelerated redox kinetics of Li-S batteries. Finally, the catalytic effect of LaNiO3 on Li2S nucleation and precipitation was also studied by discharging the batteries assembled with LaNiO3 calcined at different temperatures at a constant current (0.112 mA) to a potential of 2.06 V, followed by electrostatic discharging at a voltage of 2.05 V [1,61,62]. As observed in the electrostatic discharge curves of different catalysts in Fig. 4(d–f), the cell with the 800 °C LaNiO3-electrode exhibits a much higher current of 0.11 mA and a larger capacity of Li2S precipitation of 537 mA h g−1 than that with the 600 °C (0.07 mA, 467 mA h g−1) and 1000 °C (0.06 mA, 433 mA h g−1) LaNiO3-electrode. These results strongly demonstrate that the high electrical conductivity and catalytic activity of 800 °C LaNiO3 nanoparticles considerably improve the polysulfide conversion kinetics. Overall, due to the different morphology and structure of the materials calcined at different temperatures, it shows much different adsorption performance, catalytic property, and conductivity. The 600 °C LaNiO3 displays strong adsorption performance; however, due to its weak electrical conductivity, the active sites on its surface are long-term occupied by polysulfides. While the inadequate adsorption capacity of 1000 °C LaNiO3 leads to insufficient anchoring of polysulfides. Contrarily, 800 °C LaNiO3 possesses not only appropriate adsorption but also excellent conductivity and catalytic activity, resulting in the effective immobilization of the polysulfides, as well as fast electron transfer and increased redox kinetics to carry out fast polysulfide conversion. Therefore, in this study, we provide an effective strategy coupling the blocking with dredging to stop the polysulfide shuttle. During the operation of the Li-S battery with the common functional separator with strong affinity, a large number of polysulfides are generated, resulting in severe aggregation of polysulfides on the separator. Finally, the functional separator fails to prevent the polysulfides from rushing to the Li anode. While the three-in-one functional separator can not only block the polysulfides but also quickly convert them without aggregation, thus effectively keeping its durability. In order to futher study the anchoring and catalytic effect of LaNiO3 on polysulfides, DFT calculations were performed. Fig. 5 (a) shows that the adsorption energies of Li2S, Li2S2, Li2S4, Li2S6, and Li2S8 on La2O3 surface are −3.30, −5.63, −4.44, −3.87, and −5.49 eV, respectively. In addition, the adsorption energies of Li2S, Li2S2, Li2S4, Li2S6, and Li2S8 on LaNiO3 surface are −4.96, −5.09, −4.25, −3.82, and −4.37 eV, respectively (Fig. 5b). It can be seen from Fig. 5(a and b) that both La2O3 and LaNiO3 show strong affinity towards polysulfides through strong La–S and Li–O bonds. It can be seen from Fig. 5(c) that on both La2O3 and LaNiO3 substrates, the conversion from Li2S2 to Li2S is the non-spontaneous process and the rate-determining step [61,63,64]. However, the involvement of Ni element greatly increases the catalytic ability of LaNiO3 material. As shown in Fig. 5(c), the free energy differentials of conversion reaction from Li2S2 to Li2S on LaNiO3 surface is 1.08 eV, which is much smaller than that on La2O3 surface (3.27 eV) suggesting dramatically reduced reaction energy barrier on LaNiO3 surface. Therefore, LaNiO3 can not only anchor the polysulfides but also significantly promote the conversion reaction kinetics of polysulfides. Next, in situ Raman testing of the battery was performed to understand the effect of the 800 °C LaNiO3 on the performance of the Li-S battery during cycling, as shown in Fig. 6 . The construction of the cell for in situ Raman test is depicted in Fig. S15(a), where LaNiO3-based functional layer is coated directly to the sulfur cathode rather than the separator. The result shows that the Li-S battery can also provide long-term cycling stability after 300 cycles with a high capacity of 641 mA h g−1 (Fig. S15a). Moreover, it is found that such a Li-S battery also shows typical redox behaviors of Li-S batteries (Fig. S15b and c). Fig. 6(a) demonstrates that there are two strong peaks at 165 and 236 cm−1 in the first platform, which are ascribed to the presence of S8 2− at the beginning of the discharge process of S cathode using 800 °C LaNiO3 coating, suggesting that rich Li2S8 is released from the S cathode [65–67]. As the discharge process progresses, the signals of S8 2− gradually vanish with the appearance of new peaks at 273 and 370 cm−1, which is caused by long-chain and medium-chain polysulfides. The signals for Li2S6 and Li2S4 are noticeably stronger when the voltage drops to the second platform, implying the transition from Li2S6 to Li2S4 [68]. The peaks for S8 2−, S4 2−, and S4 2−+ S6 2− during charging are also present, as indicated in Fig. 6(b). Moreover, to intuitively show the advantages of 800 °C LaNiO3, the S cathode is prepared without the coating material. Fig. 6(d–f) shows when such a S cathode is applied to the battery, the peak signal of S4 2−+S6 2− is particularly strong, indicating the serious shuttle effect and irreversible LiPSs loss. In addition, the signal of the polysulfides lasts longer with the S cathode without coating due to the slow polysulfide conversion. On the other hand, weaker and shorter polysulfide signals are observed with the S cathode using 800 °C LaNiO3 coating, resulting from its excellent catalytic and conductive properties, which form the basis for the extended cycle performance of the battery. Furthermore, the suppressed shuttle effect by 800 °C LaNiO3 functional materials under concentration gradient and electric field driving force was also discussed by assembling in situ batteries. Fig. 7 (a and b) depicts the discharge curves of the S electrode without/with 800 °C LaNiO3-coating layer at 0.2 C, respectively. The discharge platform of the in situ battery using the S electrode coated with 800 °C LaNiO3 is more stable than the battery utilizing a bare S cathode, indicating that the polysulfide dissolution and shuttle are significantly inhibited. Fig. 7(c) displays the digital photo of an in situ battery employing the bare S electrode. It is observed that the color of the electrolyte begins to turn yellow after 15 min of discharge, which becomes more profound and turns deep yellow with prolonged discharge. This change is attributed to poor adsorption and conversion of polysulfides by the bare S cathode (without 800 °C LaNiO3), which could not prevent the shuttle effect of polysulfides effectively. Fig. 7(d) shows the digital images taken at different time periods during the discharge of the in situ battery using the S electrode coated with 800 °C LaNiO3. Interestingly, after 15 min of discharge of the in situ battery using the S electrode coating with 800 °C LaNiO3, the color of the electrolyte is nearly identical to the original one, which gradually becomes pale yellow after 30 min of discharge. The results again show that 800 °C LaNiO3 has a good adsorption ability during the operation of Li-S batteries and can better promote the catalytic conversion of polysulfides and more effectively hinder the shuttle of polysulfides. To further explore the commercial application of Li-S battery, high-loading S active material was coated on carbon paper. As seen from Fig. S16, the resulting Li-S battery with high sulfur loading still demonstrats the characteristic behavior of Li-S systems when the active sulfur loading was increased to 4.12 and 6.05 mg cm−2. Fig. 8 (a) depicts the long cycle test of Li-S batteries using a PP separator and 800 °C LaNiO3-separator at a current density of 1.2 mA cm−2. The findings demonstrate that the Li-S battery with high sulfur loading of 4.12 mg cm−2 is cycled steadily for 100 cycles and yet maintains a high specific capacity of 545 mA h g−1. However, the high-loading Li-S battery using the PP separator experiences a sudden failure after 28 stable cycles, which is due to the serious shuttle effect, greatly affecting the life of the battery, as seen in Fig. S17. Notably, the area-specific capacity is a crucial index to determine the total capacity of each electrode and the energy density of the battery [69–71]. The area-specific capacities obtained under increasing high S loadings (from 2.56, 3.33, 4.12 to 5.34 mg cm−2) are shown in Fig. 8(b), along with the superior cycle performance of the Li-S batteries. In addition, the Li-S battery with higher S loading of 6.05 mg cm−2 cycles stably at 0.8 mA cm−2 for 150 cycles with an areal capacity of 2.81 mA h cm−2 (Fig. 8c). Thus, the outstanding cycling performances of high-loading Li-S batteries demonstrate the advantage of the three-in-one LaNiO3 functional separator. In addition, from Fig. 8(a and c), when the sulfur loading is 4.12 and 6.05 mg cm−2, the Coulombic efficiency of Li-S battery with 800 °C LaNiO3-separator can still maintain 98.07% and 98.10% after 100 and 150 cycles, respectively. Therefore, even when the sulfur loading increases, the 800 °C LaNiO3-separator can still effectively suppress the shuttle effect. Next, the lean electrolyte test was conducted to investigate the commercial application of Li-S batteries using 800 °C LaNiO3-separators. It is observed that the Li-S battery delivers a high area-specific capacity of 5.98 mA h cm−2 after 40 cycles at S loading of 12.45 mg cm−2 with 7 µL mg−1 electrolyte (Fig. 8d). Later on, the cycle test of the Li-S battery containing 800 °C LaNiO3 functional material was performed by increasing the S content to 64%. The high specific capacity of 760 mA h g−1 after 60 cycles is observed at sulfur loading of 5.14 mg cm−2 with 8 µL mg−1 electrolyte (Fig. S18). Thus, it is concluded that 800 °C LaNiO3-separator can effectively block polysulfides and enhance the redox kinetics of adsorbed polysulfides to achieve their quick conversion. 4 Conclusions In summary, a three-in-one LaNiO3 with excellent catalytic performance, electrical conductivity, and strong affinity was prepared and applied to construct a multifunctional polysulfide stopper for a high-performance Li-S battery. A series of physical/chemical property studies on LaNiO3 synthesized at three calcination temperatures (600, 800, and 1000 °C) determined that 800 °C LaNiO3 possessed excellent conductivity, catalytic, and adsorption properties. Notably, the cycle stability of the battery utilizing an 800 °C LaNiO3 modified separator was greatly enhanced with improved redox kinetics and reversibility. As a result, the high capacity of 658 mA h g−1 was achieved after 500 cycles under the high current density of 2 C. In addition, it provided an areal capacity of 2.81 mA h cm−2 after 150 cycles when the S loading was 6.05 mg cm−2, indicating a great application potential. The battery with 800 °C LaNiO3-separator still exhibited outstanding and stable cycle performance when the amount of electrolyte was reduced and the S loading was increased. Specifically, the battery provided a high area-specific capacity of 5.98 mA h cm−2 after 40 cycles at S loading of 12.45 mg cm−2 with 7 µL mg−1 electrolyte. This work demonstrates the significant advantages of three-in-one LaNiO3 as modified materials for Li-S battery separators and offers a new direction for Li-S batteries research. coredata.dc:description: The lithium-sulfur (Li-S) battery, as one of the energy storage devices, has been in the limelight due to its high theoretical energy density. However, the poor redox kinetics and the “shuttle effect” of polysulfides severely restrict the use of Li-S batteries in practical applications. Herein, a novel bimetallic LaNiO3 functional material with high electrical conductivity and catalytic property is prepared to act as a high-efficiency polysulfide shuttling stopper. The three LaNiO3 samples with different physical/chemical characteristics are obtained by controlling the calcination temperature. In conjunction with the high electrical conductivity and excellent catalytic properties of the as-prepared materials, the appropriate chemisorption toward polysulfides offers great potential to enhance electrochemical stability for high-performance Li-S batteries. Particularly, the Li-S cell with the separator modified by such functional material gives a specific capacity of 658 mA h g−1 after 500 cycles at a high current density of 2 C. Even with high sulfur loading of 6.05 mg cm−2, the Li-S battery still exhibits an areal specific capacity of 2.81 mA h cm−2 after 150 cycles. This work paves a new avenue for the rational design of materials for separator modification in high-performance Li-S batteries.
